column99: Site Operations Manager for the Hevesy Lab
column100:
The Hevesy Laboratory has established a new position as Site Operations Manager (SOM) in order to expand the radionuclide production facilities and efficiently exploit the cyclotrons and radiochemistry in both research and development and in commercial operations.  
 
 Description of the position 
 
 The Hevesy Laboratory is a core facility at DTU Health Technology working within radiochemistry and radiopharmaceuticals. We combine research, development, and commercial production of radioactive elements, as well as GMP production of radiopharmaceuticals. The laboratory is currently growing with the recent purchase of a new cyclotron, which will start operating in 2023, and the expansion of the laboratory area. https://www.dtu.dk/nyheder/nyhed?id=%7bBA35FF60-3859-46F4-853C-E339594E0417%7d  
 
 Responsibilities and tasks 
 
 The Site Operational Manager will be responsible for Hevesy's operational group; support business growth; help identifying risks and opportunities; lead the cyclotron team and cyclotron-related R&D projects.  
 
 The SOM will report to and be a close collaborator to the Head of the Hevesy Lab, the SOM will be asked to develop long-term both research and operational plans and strategies and to recommend on-going improvements across the facility.  
 
 The new hire will also be expected to develop a strategic operational team and to build operational capability and improve efficiency.  
 
 Finally, the SOM will be responsible for the development and implementation of technology solutions aimed at building operational capability and improved efficiency; implementing a maintenance regime that minimizes machine downtime.  
 
 Qualifications 
 
 A scientific background, preferably in physics, and experience with PETtrace cyclotrons is needed. An understanding of all cyclotron-related equipment functions, system maintenance, and troubleshooting are also required.  
 
 We are looking for a candidate that: 
 Have knowledge within radiophysics  
 Possess a relevant training and experience in repairing and running PETtrace cyclotrons  
 Has good communication skills in English  
 Enjoys a collaborative environment  
 Enjoys being challenged by unforeseen situations  
 
 
 It is an advantage to have 
 Have some knowledge of Danish  
 Have knowledge of GMP  
 
 
 About the laboratory 
 
 The Hevesy Laboratory is a radiochemistry and radiopharmaceutical core facility that is part of the Health Technology department in DTU. It is located at the Risø Campus near Roskilde and counts around 40 employees. It is composed of both research and commercial production units. We offer an exciting and challenging job in an international atmosphere and collaborative environment. We are also a family-friendly workplace with flexible working hours and an informal tone.  
 
 Salary and appointment terms 
 
 The appointment will be based on the collective agreement with the Confederation of Professional Associations or other relevant union. The allowance will be agreed with the relevant union.  
 
 This is a full time position with start as soon as possible. The work place is at DTU Risø Campus.  
 
 Application and contact 
 
 Please submit your online application no later than 13 May 2022 (Danish time)  
 
 The application must include the following documents (combined in a single pdf file):  Application letter (max. one page, in English)  
 CV  
 Copy of relevant certificates and diploma  
 
 
 If you would like additional information about the position, please contact senior Professor Mikael Jensen (kmje@dtu.dk) or Head of Section Jørgen Schøller (jorsh@dtu.dk).  
 
 Applications are evaluated and interviews are carried out on an ongoing basis.  
 
 All interested candidates irrespective of age, gender, race, disability, religion or ethnic background are encouraged to apply.  
 
 Technology for people 
 
 DTU develops technology for people. With our international elite research and study programmes, we are helping to create a better world and to solve the global challenges formulated in the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals. Hans Christian Ørsted founded DTU in 1829 with a clear vision to develop and create value using science and engineering to benefit society. That vision lives on today. DTU has 13,400 students and 5,800 employees. We work in an international atmosphere and have an inclusive, evolving, and informal working environment. DTU has campuses in all parts of Denmark and in Greenland, and we collaborate with the best universities around the world.
